pros: Good pay Good working conditions
cons: long hours long night shifts

job_title: Security Team Member in Edinburgh, Scotland
pros: Autonomy on the job, good colleagues, flexible hours
cons: Some supervisors very prone to micro-management or ego tripping, sometimes incl. bars manager, unclear expectations on the job, clique-ish attitude, esp. on shift assignment

pros: Good organisation to work for
cons: Low pay for the responsibility assumed

pros: They were a very supportive employer and dealt with any problems well. Good for casual uni work
cons: The pay was okay but sometimes difficult to book shifts at convenient times

pros: Flexible hours Good pay Nice staff
cons: Inconsistent hours available Work is sometimes slow

pros: Poor management and zero hour contract
cons: Friendly place to work and meet fellow students.

review_title: Flexible Job for a Student; Weirdly Corporate for a Nonprofit
job_title: Venue Operations Team Member in Edinburgh, Scotland
pros: - Duty Managers are helpful and supportive - Flexible with setting your daily availability since most employees are students - Generally good atmosphere and nice people - Zero-hours contract makes it easy to take time off for studying, seeing family, etc. - Free taxi home provided if working past 11pm - Zero-tolerance policy on harassment; staff know that if a customer harasses them verbally or otherwise, security and management will support them. Most staff carry radios, so it is easy to call security any time they're on shift. - Understanding that staff's health and safety is paramount; if a staff member is unwell they're allowed to go home early without feeling guilty.
cons: - Unpredictable hours - For a nonprofit organisation, upper management is very focused on revenue and this has led staff's feeling of security/morale to decrease - No food provided, cafe staff not allowed free coffee, chefs not allowed to make free food for staff, bar staff not allowed free coke/lemonade etc. - Chronically understaffed; minimal venue operations & bar staff are assigned to shifts so that those working on busy nights are overwhelmed and overworked; when shifts are quiet enough to be un-stressful, staff are sent home early to save paying them - Weird emphasis on staff appearing 'perfect', e.g. I've seen staff told off for drinking water in a customer-facing space, wearing the wrong color of shoes. No student union customer cares about these things. - Breaks are an unpaid 30 minutes for shifts over 6 hours, nothing more for longer shifts. While a common practice, this can be rough.

job_title: Vice President Welfare in Edinburgh, Scotland
pros: Great work-life balance, strong social impact, contribution to positive student experience.
cons: Lack of diversity at management level, lethargic actions on diversity and inclusion

pros: Flexible working hours during term time, as many shifts as you could ever want during Fringe
cons: Stressful Team Leader role with more responsibility than a Team Member for barely any extra pay. Chronically understaffed during Fringe, clique-y venue culture, some truly horrific experiences working at Big Cheese

job_title: Human Resources Coordinator in Edinburgh, Scotland
pros: The people, nice to be surrounded by students, good overall values and beliefs.
cons: Pay, development opportunities, high turnover, organisational and inter-departmental communication.

review_title: Good place for flexible/part time work
pros: Lovely staff and friendly work environment!
cons: Facilities could do with sprucing up - especially the staff room

review_title: No longer really a student union
pros: Respected zero hours contract. Made many friends whilst working there.
cons: HR only exists for the Head Office staff not for the students it hires (even though it is a student union that should be most interested in the welfare of its students). Has recently become very cut throat and commercial. Absolutely no benefits for its employees (though I'm sure members of Head Office have ample benefits).

job_title: Bar Team Member in Edinburgh, Scotland
pros: Very considerate of your own schedule and priorities. Since it is run for students they are very good at accommodating employees needs who are often students or alumni.
cons: Relatively low pay but this is standard for bar work. Students are less likely to tip.

job_title: Catering Service Manager in Edinburgh, Scotland
pros: Very good communication. Strong Support. Open to ideas
cons: You need to chase up things to get it done. If you want something done right, do it yourself.

job_title: House Team Leader in Edinburgh, Scotland
pros:
- very social environment! Everyone is very welcoming and fun 
- decent pay for a student job
- pretty streamlined work day
- fun to be in the heart of student life
cons:
- upper management staff (anything above duty managers) can be really condescending and awful to actual staff but if you’re not a manager/team leader you don’t have to deal with them
- can be a bit disorganised but has gotten a lot better

job_title: Welcome Team Member in Edinburgh, Scotland
pros: So flexible whilst studying at Edinburgh university
cons: I can’t think of any, such an amazing organisation to work for if you are a student looking for part time work.

pros: work with great people very friendly
cons: repetitive work sometimes is not very interesting

job_title: Front of House Team Member in Edinburgh, Scotland
pros: Great job if you are a student who wants to work while studying. The hours are flexible and you can work whenever you are available. The rest of the staff are also very friendly - is a great community.
cons: Not really a con but make sure you are able to deal with difficult/drunk customers as this can happen especially if working in evenings.

pros: Good company and colleagues at work
cons: Not good academic teaching at times

pros: Amazing diverse university experience, in which both sport/ extra curriculum activities are valued just as must as academic achievements
cons: their ethnic diversity could be improved

pros:

Festival Is fantastic Experience

Demanding Hours

job_title: Welcome Team Member in Edinburgh, Scotland
pros: Great training and lovely people, so flexible around university timetable
cons: Be prepared to multitask and speak to lots of people

pros:
- Positive encouragement from Team Leaders 
- Flexibility and understanding of student schedule

cons: Hard to balance alongside studies

pros: very flexible hours, so great for students. Fun place to work, everyone from TMs to DMs are friendly.

review_title: Flexible place to work as a student
job_title: Bars Team Member in Edinburgh, Scotland
pros: Very flexible with hours to suit those studying.
cons: Training could be more comprehensive

pros: Great team to work with.
cons: Most bar staff are on zero hour contracts and hours are often limited.

pros: Great people. A good way to network.
cons: Not enough hours offered at times.

job_title: Catering Team Leader in Edinburgh, Scotland
pros: Flexible working hours that are great for students.

Decent pay with tips
Flexible
Good Culture and Colleagues

pros: Good work for students as part time
cons:
Pay isn't the best
zero hour contract

review_title: An excellent part-time student job, and a great Festival experience
job_title: House Team Leader in Edinburgh, Scotland
pros:
The management are very flexible and understanding about outside commitments (e.g., study deadlines). It's a zero-hours contract, but they don't abuse it, and I always felt that management were as fair as possible when allocating hours to staff.
The management were quite serious about encouraging personal development, and reflection on your work. You get the impression they do care about the well-being of their staff.
There's a really good social side to the job, with lots of opportunities for socialising with colleagues. It occasionally felt a little bit cliquey, but never overly so.
If you're working there during the Festival it's a good way to make money - consistent shift patterns, lots of training (all paid), and pretty easy work.
cons: Wages should have been higher (ideally a true Living Wage), but they're not as bad as other employers in the hospitality/customer service sector.

pros:
paid 21yr old minimum wage even if younger, as I was this was more than similar jobs would have given
as is student union is understanding of lifestyle/commitments (to an extent)
initially a relatively planned shift pattern allowing to plan life 2 weeks in advance
cons:
increasingly low morale/erratic management higher up was leading to controversial decisions and low morale, this led to significant staff turnover and difficulties with shift patterns which ultimately damaged work life balance
resourcing of department varied by location some sites had adequate equipment/material others did not
pay scandal involving phantom book keeping whilst I was there though was largely suppressed internally

review_title: Good hours and management who understand the work / study balance
job_title: Welcome Team Member in Edinburgh, Scotland
pros: Good management within administration department, good hours that take into account student status (don't ask too much of your time - generally 15 hours or less), pay sufficient compensation for the type of work. The job itself isn't all that hard, and if nobody is coming to the desk and you have no tasks to complete or bookings / memberships to process then you can often get some uni work done. Also coworkers are very friendly and fun to work with.
cons: Training isn't fantastic, but you learn pretty quickly how to do things when you're on shift.

review_title: Fun and flexible place to work
pros:
-Flexibility with hours, only working when you are available to and able to easily swap shifts
-Fun working environment and great social scene outside of work - met loads of friends here and it improved my uni experience 
-Discount on food and drink
-Free shows in the fringe, which was amazing!
cons:
-Little or no engagement from the bars manager, didn't really know them
-I worked on an extremely busy bar during the fringe which was very challenging, managing 8+ members of staff. It was a compliment to be given this responsibility, however, I wasn't paid any more than someone managing one other person on a quieter bar. That's life though!

review_title: Absolutely loved my time working in bars at EUSA
job_title: Bars Team Leader in Edinburgh, Scotland
pros:
Great culture, flexible hours, student-friendly management, safe environment, quick promotions, diesel. 

Pretty much the perfect student job, and where I made the most friends at uni. Also fantastic if you work during the festival.
cons:
Management has the potential to be politicised by short-term student executives. 

Timetables can be fairly inconsistent due to the number of staff employed. Suits part-time work (i.e. students).

review_title: I have worked for EUSA bars team for almost a year on a part time basis.
pros:
Very flexible hours, which is ideal for students.
Training available for those who are interested.
Interesting and fun recruitment day.
cons:
Very inefficient at times. The closing procedures take a lot longer than they should. 
Lack of supervision.
Lack of "community feeling". Everybody seemed to be grouped up and not really interested in new staff members.

review_title: Nice people, you can often choose when to work and good range of locations available
pros: I really liked working here as a student, it was good fun and a good entry in bartending. Straightforward system for logging your availability and picking up shifts and was a good way to earn money during term time :)
cons: Sometimes a bit disorganised and a lot of staff so you didn't work with the same people regularly

review_title: Great for flexible, term-time paid work
pros: Easy to set availability around university and other commitments, as well as to pick up additional shifts when you have the time
cons: Not the most intellectually stimulating or demanding job around - day-to-day responsibilities revolve around basic customer service, maintenance of the retail space, and, if you work in King's Buildings, food preparation for the deli.

job_title: Retail Team Member in Edinburgh, Scotland
pros: Was so flexible to work around uni classes, easy to swap and pick up shifts where needed. The salaried staff were lovely.
cons: Not great for communication with managers. Since the company is so big there were lots of people so hard to build close relationships with other staff.

review_title: Fun place to work with great people! - Bars Team
job_title: Bars Team Leader in Edinburgh, Scotland
pros: Easy working environment.  Everyone who they hire is really friendly and easy going.
cons: Because of 0 hour contract, they hire more people than needed and you may not get scheduled as often as you'd like.

job_title: Security Team Member in Edinburgh, Scotland
pros: Easy interview, they hire students left and right. Good part time paying job during uni.
cons: Some of the managers have no self awareness. Pay is meh

pros: can choose when you want to work, can not work for up to 4 months, everyone is very friendly and very understanding when you can't work.
cons: a lot of pointless training but get paid for it so makes it less bad

pros: Recruitment process was really quick, I think they were slightly desperate for staff over the Fringe. Manager's were really friendly and approachable.
cons: It could be slightly disorganised at times and the staff areas left a lot to be desired.

pros:
- flexibility to work around your schedule as a student
- meet lots of new people
- good pay for part-time work
cons:
- can be disorganised at times
- hard to get shifts at times.

job_title: Catering Team Member in Edinburgh, Scotland
pros: Flexible working hours, you can pick your shift according to academic schedule, friendly work colleagues, opportunity to work full time during the Fringe.
cons: Not many, standard minimum wage paying job.

job_title: Retail Team Leader in Edinburgh, Scotland
pros:
Hours that work around class schedules
Holiday pay
Easy enough job
cons:
Multiple locations to work and you don't get to choose which you work in
Have to live close to the main University campus

review_title: Good employer, flexible, easy to work with

job_title: Retail Senior Team Leader in Edinburgh, Scotland

Retail managers are friendly and helpful
Staff generally good to work with
Not an overly difficult job, until festival time
cons: Poor salary for what is essentially a store manager job

review_title: Nice place to have a part-time job.
pros: Nice and friendly colleagues. Reasonable management team, with some exceptions.   Paid taxi if finishing late.
cons: No personal lockers. Nothing else comes to mind.

pros: Flexible working hours and good training
cons: Such a big staff there's not much community

Flexible working
Work-life balance encouraged and supported
